1 These items weigh one-quarter this amount when made for Small characters. Containers for Small characters also carry one-quarter the normal amount.
2 Relative to similar armor made for a Medium humanoid.
3 See spell description for additional costs. If the additional costs put the spell's total cost above 3,000 gp, that spell is not generally available. Use a spell level of 1/2 for 0-level spells to calculate the cost.
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Table Goods and Services
sections.name: Table: Goods and Services

sections.body: Beyond armor and weapons, a character can carry a whole variety of gear, from rations (to sustain him on long travels), to rope (which is useful in countless circumstances). Most of the common gear carried by adventurers is summarized on Table: Goods and Services.
Some of the pieces of adventuring gear found on Table: Goods and Services are described below, along with any special benefits they confer on the user (“you”).
sections.name: Adventuring Gear

sections.body: This leather knapsack has one large pocket that closes with a buckled strap and holds about 2 cubic feet of material. Some may have one or more smaller pockets on the sides.
sections.name: Backpack

sections.body: This is a sturdy wooden barrel with a tight-fitting lid, banded with metal.
sections.name: Barrel

sections.body: This large basket has a lid and holds about 2 cubic feet.
sections.name: Basket

sections.body: This consists of two woolen sheets sewn together along the bottom and one side to create a bag for sleeping in. Some have cloth straps along the open side so the bedroll can be tied closed while you are sleeping. It can be rolled and tied into a tight coil for storage or transport. Most people use a blanket with the bedroll to stay warm or provide a ground cushion.
sections.name: Bedroll

sections.body: This handbell can produce only one loud note.
sections.name: Bell

sections.body: A typical leather or cloth belt pouch has a leather cord to cinch it shut and another to tie it to your belt. It is large enough to hold 100–200 coins or two apples.
sections.name: Belt Pouch
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Belt Pouch

sections.body: This warm, woven blanket has straps so it can be rolled up and tied. Blankets are often used in conjunction with bedrolls to provide additional warmth or a ground cushion.
sections.name: Blanket

sections.body: Whether it is used to hoist treasure from a pit or move supplies, a simple block-and-tackle pulley, when it is properly secured, adds a +5 circumstance bonus on Strength checks to lift heavy objects. Securing the pulley requires 1 minute.
sections.name: Block and Tackle
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Block and Tackle

sections.body: This glass bottle holds about a pint and includes a cork.
sections.name: Bottle

sections.body: A typical bucket has a rope handle and can hold 1–2 gallons of liquid.
sections.name: Bucket

sections.body:
A caltrop is a four-pronged metal spike crafted so that one prong faces up no matter how the caltrop comes to rest. You scatter caltrops on the ground in the hope that your enemies step on them or are at least forced to slow down to avoid them. One 2-pound bag of caltrops covers an area 5 feet square.

Each time a creature moves into an area covered by caltrops (or spends a round fighting while standing in such an area), it runs the risk of stepping on one. Make an attack roll for the caltrops (base attack bonus +0) against the creature. For this attack, the creature's shield, armor, and deflection bonuses do not count. If the creature is wearing shoes or other footwear, it gets a +2 armor bonus to AC. If the attack succeeds, the creature has stepped on a caltrop. The caltrop deals 1 point of damage, and the creature's speed is reduced by half because its foot is wounded. This movement penalty lasts for 24 hours, until the creature is successfully treated with a DC 15 Heal check, or until it receives at least 1 point of magical healing. A charging or running creature must immediately stop if it steps on a caltrop. Any creature moving at half speed or slower can pick its way through a bed of caltrops with no trouble.

Caltrops may not work against unusual opponents.
sections.name: Caltrops

sections.body: A candle dimly illuminates a small area, increasing the light level in a 5-foot radius by one step (darkness becomes dim light and dim light becomes normal light). A candle cannot increase the light level above normal light. A candle burns for 1 hour.
sections.name: Candle

sections.body: This square yard of heavy cloth is suitable for painting, for covering items in a rainstorm, for creating a sail, or as an improvised bag. It is not waterproof but can be treated with oil, wax, or resin to make it water-resistant.
sections.name: Canvas

sections.body: Chain has hardness 10 and 5 hit points. It can be burst with a DC 26 Strength check.
sections.name: Chain

sections.body: This fat piece of white chalk easily marks wood, metal, or stone. You can write with it for about 24 hours before it is expended. Chalk also comes in other colors, but these are rarer and can be more expensive.
sections.name: Chalk

sections.body: A common small wooden chest (2 cubic feet, 1 hit point, break DC 17). Most include a simple inset lock.
sections.name: Chest

sections.body: A crowbar grants a +2 circumstance bonus on Strength checks made to force open a door or chest. If used in combat, treat a crowbar as a one-handed improvised weapon that deals bludgeoning damage equal to that of a club of its size.
sections.name: Crowbar

sections.body: This bundle of dry wood includes twigs and logs.
sections.name: Firewood

sections.body: This metal hook is little more than a stiff, bent needle.
sections.name: Fishhook

sections.body: This net measures 5 feet by 5 feet, and can be used to cover a pit or to block Tiny or larger creatures from entering an area.
sections.name: Fishing Net
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Fishing Net

sections.body: This glass bottle holds 1 pint. It is relatively fragile and breaks if thrown at a creature or hard surface. Flasks may be simple blown glass, or they may be elaborate affairs embossed with family crests and other artwork.
sections.name: Flask

sections.body: Lighting a torch with flint and steel is a full-round action, and lighting any other fire with them takes at least that long.
sections.name: Flint and Steel
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Flint and Steel

sections.body: Throwing a grappling hook requires a ranged attack roll, treating the hook as a thrown weapon with a range increment of 10 feet. Objects with ample places to catch the hook are AC 5.
sections.name: Grappling Hook
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Grappling Hook

sections.body: If a hammer is used in combat, treat it as a one-handed improvised weapon that deals bludgeoning damage equal to that of a spiked gauntlet of its size.
sections.name: Hammer

sections.body: The standard hourglass takes 1 hour to empty the sand from the upper chamber.
sections.name: Hourglass

sections.body: Ink in colors other than black costs twice as much.
sections.name: Ink

sections.body: This is a wooden stylus with a metal tip that retains a small amount of ink after you dip it in a vial of ink.
sections.name: Inkpen

sections.body: This basic jug is fitted with a stopper and holds 1 gallon of liquid.
sections.name: Jug, Clay

sections.body: This simple 10-foot ladder consists of two long boards with wooden steps nailed into them at 1-foot increments.
sections.name: Ladder

sections.body: A lamp illuminates a small area, providing normal light in a 15-foot radius and increasing the light level by one step for an additional 15 feet beyond that area (darkness becomes dim light and dim light becomes normal light). A lamp does not increase the light level in normal light or bright light. A lamp burns for 6 hours on one pint of oil. You can carry a lamp in one hand.
sections.name: Lamp, Common

sections.body: A bullseye lantern provides normal light in a 60-foot cone and increases the light level by one step in the area beyond that, out to a 120-foot cone (darkness becomes dim light and dim light becomes normal light). A bullseye lantern does not increase the light level in normal light or bright light. A lantern burns for 6 hours on one pint of oil. You can carry a lantern in one hand.
sections.name: Lantern, Bullseye

sections.body: A hooded lantern sheds normal light in a 30-foot radius and increases the light level by one step for an additional 30 feet beyond that area (darkness becomes dim light and dim light becomes normal light). A hooded lantern does not increase the light level in normal light or bright light. A lantern burns for 6 hours on one pint of oil. You can carry a lantern in one hand.
sections.name: Lantern, Hooded

sections.body: The DC to open a lock with the Disable Device skill depends on the lock's quality: simple (DC 20), average (DC 25), good (DC 30), or superior (DC 40).
sections.name: Lock

sections.body:
Manacles can bind a Medium creature. A manacled creature can use the Escape Artist skill to slip free (DC 30, or DC 35 for masterwork manacles). Breaking the manacles requires a Strength check (DC 26, or DC 28 for masterwork manacles). Manacles have hardness 10 and 10 hit points.

Most manacles have locks; add the cost of the lock you want to the cost of the manacles.

For the same cost, you can buy manacles for a Small creature. For a Large creature, manacles cost 10 times the indicated amount, and for a Huge creature, 100 times the indicated amount. Gargantuan, Colossal, Tiny, Diminutive, and Fine creatures can be held only by specially made manacles, which cost at least 100 times the indicated amount.
sections.name: Manacles, Standard and Masterwork
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Manacles/Standard and Masterwork

sections.body: This hand-held mirror is about a foot across. Unlike many higher-quality glass mirrors, this one is made out of polished steel and sturdy enough that you can drop it without risk of breakage.
sections.name: Mirror

sections.body: Whether it is a simple pottery cup or an elaborate drinking stein with a handle and decorative lid that flips up, this cup may be used to hold any sort of beverage. Tankards are commonly made out of clay or tin.
sections.name: Mug/Tankard

sections.body:
A pint of oil burns for 6 hours in a lantern or lamp. You can also use a flask of oil as a splash weapon. Use the rules for alchemist's fire (see Special Substances and Items on Table: Goods and Services), except that it takes a full-round action to prepare a flask with a fuse. Once it is thrown, there is a 50% chance of the flask igniting successfully.

You can pour a pint of oil on the ground to cover an area 5 feet square, provided that the surface is smooth. If lit, the oil burns for 2 rounds and deals 1d3 points of fire damage to each creature in the area.
sections.name: Oil

sections.body: This sheet of thin, treated animal skin is a durable writing surface and is suitable for making magic scrolls. It has hardness 0, 2 hit points, and a break DC of 5.
sections.name: Parchment

sections.body: A sheet of ordinary paper typically measures 9 inches by 6 inches and is unsuitable for making magical scrolls. It has hardness 0, 1 hit point, and a break DC of 5.
sections.name: Paper

sections.body: If a miner's pick is used in combat, treat it as a two-handed improvised weapon that deals piercing damage equal to that of a heavy pick of its size.
sections.name: Pick, Miner's

sections.body: This basic clay pitcher has a handle and an open top with a groove for easy pouring. It holds 1/2 gallon of liquid. The listed weight is for a pitcher filled with water, wine, or ale; empty, it weighs about 1/2 pound.
sections.name: Pitcher

sections.body: A piton is an iron spike with a loop or ring on the end so you can tie a rope to it.
sections.name: Piton

sections.body: This 10-foot length of wood is useful for probing pits, flagstones, and murky liquids from a safe distance.
sections.name: Pole

sections.body: This 8-inch-diameter iron pot is sturdy and has feet, a lid, and a rounded handle. It can hold enough stew to feed one hungry human for one meal. A mithral pot is lighter and food rarely sticks to it.
sections.name: Pot

sections.body: This iron-shod wooden beam gives you a +2 circumstance bonus on Strength checks made to break open a door and allows a second person to help, automatically increasing your bonus by 2.
sections.name: Ram, Portable

sections.body: This rope has 2 hit points and can be burst with a DC 23 Strength check.
sections.name: Rope, Hemp

sections.body: This rope has 4 hit points and can be burst with a DC 24 Strength check.
sections.name: Rope, Silk

sections.body: This heavy canvas sack, useful for carrying adventuring gear and other supplies, holds about 4 cubic feet. A leather thong threaded through loops at the bag's end allows it to be tied shut easily.
sections.name: Sack

sections.body: A leather or wooden scroll case easily holds four scrolls; you can cram more inside, but retrieving any of them becomes a full-round action rather than a move action. You must destroy the scroll case to damage its contents (hardness 2 for leather or 5 for wood, 2 hit points, break DC 15). A scroll case is not watertight, and must still be protected from the elements.
sections.name: Scroll Case
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Scroll Case

sections.body: This stick of red wax is used to seal envelopes, often using an impression from a signet ring as proof they were sent by you.
sections.name: Sealing Wax
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Sealing Wax

sections.body: This needle allows you to stitch together cloth, canvas, or thin leather.
sections.name: Sewing Needle
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Sewing Needle

sections.body: If a shovel is used in combat, treat it as a one-handed improvised weapon that deals bludgeoning damage equal to that of a club of its size.
sections.name: Shovel

sections.body: With a DC 5 Perform (wind instruments) check, you can use a whistle to signal the same sorts of situations as signal horns. A whistle's piercing report can be clearly heard (Perception DC 0) up to a quarter-mile away. For each quarter-mile beyond, Perception checks to hear a whistle take a –2 penalty. Silent whistles that only animals and other creatures with keen hearing can hear also exist.
sections.name: Signal Whistle
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Signal Whistle

sections.body: This ring has an embossed design, typically a family crest or official icon. You press a signet ring into softened wax to leave an impression of this symbol.
sections.name: Signet Ring
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Signet Ring

sections.body: This heavy, two-handed hammer is normally used in carpentry and other construction tasks, and is also useful for driving in tent stakes to help secure campsites in areas with strong winds. If used in combat, treat it as an improvised earth breaker (see page 27).
sections.name: Sledge

sections.body: Most soap is made from animal fat and lye derived from ashes. You can use this thick block of soap to scrub clothes, pots, linens, adventurers, or anything else that might be dirty. A bar of soap has approximately 50 uses.
sections.name: Soap

sections.body: Objects viewed through a spyglass are magnified to twice their size. Characters using a spyglass take a –1 penalty on Perception skill checks per 20 feet of distance to the target, if the target is visible.
sections.name: Spyglass

sections.body: A small tents. Holds one Medium creature and takes 20 minutes to assemble. Packing up a tent takes half as long as assembling it.
sections.name: Tent

sections.body: A torch burns for 1 hour, shedding normal light in a 20-foot radius and increasing the light level by one step for an additional 20 feet beyond that area (darkness becomes dim light and dim light becomes normal light). A torch does not increase the light level in normal light or bright light. If a torch is used in combat, treat it as a one-handed improvised weapon that deals bludgeoning damage equal to that of a gauntlet of its size, plus 1 point of fire damage.
sections.name: Torch

sections.body: The listed price is for a day's worth of food. This bland food is usually some kind of hard tack, jerky, and dried fruit, though the contents vary from region to region and the race of those creating it. As long as it stays dry, it can go for months without spoiling.
sections.name: Trail Rations
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Trail Rations

sections.body: A vial is made out of glass or steel and holds 1 ounce of liquid.
sections.name: Vial

sections.body: This large, bulky contrivance gives the time accurately to within half an hour per day since it was last set. It requires a source of water, and it must be kept still because it marks time by the regulated flow of droplets of water.
sections.name: Water Clock
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Water Clock

sections.body: This bag is made of an animal bladder or treated leather. It is watertight and holds about 1/2 gallon of liquid. The listed weight is for a waterskin full of water; empty, it weighs about 2 pounds.
sections.name: Waterskin

sections.body: A whetstone allows you to sharpen a blade by sliding it against the stone at a precise angle. Honing a blade with a whetstone requires about 15 minutes of work and grants the weapon a +1 bonus on your damage roll the first time you hit with it. This only works on nonmagical blades.
sections.name: Whetstone

sections.body: Any of these substances except for the everburning torch and holy water can be made by a character with the Craft (alchemy) skill.
sections.name: Special Substances and Items
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Special Substances and Items

sections.body: You can throw a flask of acid as a splash weapon. Treat this attack as a ranged touch attack with a range increment of 10 feet. A direct hit deals 1d6 points of acid damage. Every creature within 5 feet of the point where the acid hits takes 1 point of acid damage from the splash.
sections.name: Acid
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Special Substances and Items/Acid

sections.body:
You can throw a flask of alchemist's fire as a splash weapon. Treat this attack as a ranged touch attack with a range increment of 10 feet.

A direct hit deals 1d6 points of fire damage. Every creature within 5 feet of the point where the flask hits takes 1 point of fire damage from the splash. On the round following a direct hit, the target takes an additional 1d6 points of damage. If desired, the target can use a full-round action to attempt to extinguish the flames before taking this additional damage. Extinguishing the flames requires a DC 15 Reflex save. Rolling on the ground provides the target a +2 bonus on the save. Leaping into a lake or magically extinguishing the flames automatically smothers the fire.
sections.name: Alchemist's Fire
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Special Substances and Items/Alchemists Fire

sections.body: If you drink a vial of antitoxin, you get a +5 alchemical bonus on Fortitude saving throws against poison for 1 hour.
sections.name: Antitoxin
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Special Substances and Items/Antitoxin

sections.body: This otherwise normal torch has a continual flame spell cast on it. This causes it to shed light like an ordinary torch, but it does not emit heat or deal fire damage if used as a weapon.
sections.name: Everburning Torch
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Special Substances and Items/Everburning Torch

sections.body:
Holy water damages undead creatures and evil outsiders almost as if it were acid. A flask of holy water can be thrown as a splash weapon.

Treat this attack as a ranged touch attack with a range increment of 10 feet. A flask breaks if thrown against the body of a corporeal creature, but to use it against an incorporeal creature, you must open the flask and pour the holy water out onto the target. Thus, you can douse an incorporeal creature with holy water only if you are adjacent to it. Doing so is a ranged touch attack that does not provoke attacks of opportunity.

A direct hit by a flask of holy water deals 2d4 points of damage to an undead creature or an evil outsider. Each such creature within 5 feet of the point where the flask hits takes 1 point of damage from the splash.

Temples to good deities sell holy water at cost (making no profit). Holy water is made using the bless water spell.
sections.name: Holy Water
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Special Substances and Items/Holy Water

sections.body: This alchemically treated wooden stick instantly creates thick, opaque smoke when burned. The smoke fills a 10-foot cube (treat the effect as a fog cloud spell, except that a moderate or stronger wind dissipates the smoke in 1 round). The stick is consumed after 1 round, and the smoke dissipates naturally after 1 minute.
sections.name: Smokestick
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Special Substances and Items/Smokestick

sections.body: This 1-foot-long, gold-tipped, iron rod glows brightly when struck as a standard action. It sheds normal light in a 30-foot radius and increases the light level by one step for an additional 30 feet beyond that area (darkness becomes dim light and dim light becomes normal light). A sunrod does not increase the light level in normal light or bright light. It glows for 6 hours, after which the gold tip is burned out and worthless.
sections.name: Sunrod
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Special Substances and Items/Sunrod

sections.body:
A tanglefoot bag is a small sack filled with tar, resin, and other sticky substances. When you throw a tanglefoot bag at a creature (as a ranged touch attack with a range increment of 10 feet), the bag comes apart and goo bursts out, entangling the target and then becoming tough and resilient upon exposure to air. An entangled creature takes a –2 penalty on attack rolls and a –4 penalty to Dexterity and must make a DC 15 Reflex save or be glued to the floor, unable to move. Even on a successful save, it can move only at half speed. Huge or larger creatures are unaffected by a tanglefoot bag. A flying creature is not stuck to the floor, but it must make a DC 15 Reflex save or be unable to fly (assuming it uses its wings to fly) and fall to the ground. A tanglefoot bag does not function underwater.

A creature that is glued to the floor (or unable to fly) can break free by making a DC 17 Strength check or by dealing 15 points of damage to the goo with a slashing weapon. A creature trying to scrape goo off itself, or another creature assisting, does not need to make an attack roll; hitting the goo is automatic, after which the creature that hit makes a damage roll to see how much of the goo was scraped off. Once free, the creature can move (including flying) at half speed. If the entangled creature attempts to cast a spell, it must make concentration check with a DC of 15 + the spell's level or be unable to cast the spell. The goo becomes brittle and fragile after 2d4 rounds, cracking apart and losing its effectiveness. An application of universal solvent to a stuck creature dissolves the alchemical goo immediately.
sections.name: Tanglefoot Bag
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Special Substances and Items/Tanglefoot Bag

sections.body:
You can throw this stone as a ranged attack with a range increment of 20 feet. When it strikes a hard surface (or is struck hard), it creates a deafening bang that is treated as a sonic attack. Each creature within a 10-foot-radius spread must make a DC 15 Fortitude save or be deafened for 1 hour. A deafened creature, in addition to the obvious effects, takes a –4 penalty on initiative and has a 20% chance to miscast and lose any spell with a verbal component that it tries to cast.

Since you don't need to hit a specific target, you can simply aim at a particular 5-foot square. Treat the target square as AC 5.
sections.name: Thunderstone
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Special Substances and Items/Thunderstone

sections.body: The alchemical substance on the end of this small, wooden stick ignites when struck against a rough surface. Creating a flame with a tindertwig is much faster than creating a flame with flint and steel (or a magnifying glass) and tinder. Lighting a torch with a tindertwig is a standard action (rather than a full-round action), and lighting any other fire with one is at least a standard action.
sections.name: Tindertwig
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Special Substances and Items/Tindertwig

sections.body: These items are particularly useful to characters with certain skills and class abilities.
sections.name: Tools and Skill Kits
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Tools and Skill Kits

sections.body: This lab is used for making alchemical items, and provides a +2 circumstance bonus on Craft (alchemy) checks. It has no bearing on the costs related to the Craft (alchemy) skill. Without this lab, a character with the Craft (alchemy) skill is assumed to have enough tools to use the skill but not enough to get the +2 bonus that the lab provides.
sections.name: Alchemist's Lab
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Tools and Skill Kits/Alchemists Lab

sections.body: These special tools include the items needed to pursue any craft. Without them, you have to use improvised tools (–2 penalty on Craft checks), if you can do the job at all.
sections.name: Artisan's Tools
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Tools and Skill Kits/Artisans Tools

sections.body: These tools serve the same purpose as artisan's tools, but masterwork artisan's tools are the perfect tools for the job, so you get a +2 circumstance bonus on Craft checks made with them.
sections.name: Artisan's Tools, Masterwork
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Tools and Skill Kits/Artisans Tools/Masterwork

sections.body: These crampons, pitons, ropes, and tools give you a +2 circumstance bonus on Climb checks.
sections.name: Climber's Kit
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Tools and Skill Kits/Climbers Kit

sections.body: The kit is the perfect tool for disguise and provides a +2 circumstance bonus on Disguise checks. A disguise kit is exhausted after 10 uses.
sections.name: Disguise Kit
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Tools and Skill Kits/Disguise Kit

sections.body: This collection of bandages and herbs provides a +2 circumstance bonus on Heal checks. A healer's kit is exhausted after 10 uses.
sections.name: Healer's Kit
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Tools and Skill Kits/Healers Kit

sections.body: Druids commonly use these plants as divine focuses when casting spells.
sections.name: Holly and Mistletoe
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Tools and Skill Kits/Holly and Mistletoe

sections.body: A holy symbol focuses positive energy and is used by good clerics and paladins (or by neutral clerics who want to cast good spells or channel positive energy). Each religion has its own holy symbol.
sections.name: Holy Symbol, Silver or Wooden
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Tools and Skill Kits/Holy Symbol/Silver or Wooden

sections.body: An unholy symbol is like a holy symbol except that it focuses negative energy and is used by evil clerics (or by neutral clerics who want to cast evil spells or channel negative energy).
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Tools and Skill Kits/Holy Symbol/Silver or Wooden/Unholy Symbols
sections.name: Unholy Symbols

sections.body: This simple lens allows a closer look at small objects. It is also useful as a substitute for flint and steel when starting fires. Lighting a fire with a magnifying glass requires bright light, such as sunlight to focus, tinder to ignite, and at least a full-round action. A magnifying glass grants a +2 circumstance bonus on Appraise checks involving any item that is small or highly detailed.
sections.name: Magnifying Glass
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Tools and Skill Kits/Magnifying Glass

sections.body: A masterwork instrument grants a +2 circumstance bonus on Perform checks involving its use.
sections.name: Musical Instrument, Common or Masterwork
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Tools and Skill Kits/Musical Instrument/Common or Masterwork

sections.body: A merchant's scale grants a +2 circumstance bonus on Appraise checks involving items that are valued by weight, including anything made of precious metals.
sections.name: Scale, Merchant's
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Tools and Skill Kits/Scale/Merchants

sections.body: A spellcaster with a spell component pouch is assumed to have all the material components and focuses needed for spellcasting, except for those components that have a specific cost, divine focuses, and focuses that wouldn't fit in a pouch.
sections.name: Spell Component Pouch
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Tools and Skill Kits/Spell Component Pouch

sections.body: A spellbook has 100 pages of parchment, and each spell takes up one page per spell level (one page each for 0-level spells).
sections.name: Spellbook, Wizard's
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Tools and Skill Kits/Spellbook/Wizards

sections.body: This kit contains lockpicks and other tools you need to use the Disable Device skill. Without these tools, you must use improvised tools, and you take a –2 circumstance penalty on Disable Device checks.
sections.name: Thieves' Tools
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Tools and Skill Kits/Thieves Tools

sections.body: This kit contains extra tools and tools of better make, which grant a +2 circumstance bonus on Disable Device checks.
sections.name: Thieves' Tools, Masterwork
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Tools and Skill Kits/Thieves Tools/Masterwork

sections.body: This well-made item is the perfect tool for the job. It grants a +2 circumstance bonus on a related skill check (if any). Bonuses provided by multiple masterwork items do not stack.
sections.name: Tool, Masterwork
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Tools and Skill Kits/Tool/Masterwork

sections.body: All characters begin play with one outfit, valued at 10 gp or less. Additional outfits can be purchased normally.
sections.name: Clothing

sections.body: This outfit includes a shirt with buttons, a skirt or pants with a drawstring, shoes, and perhaps a cap or hat. It may also include a belt or a leather or cloth apron for carrying tools.
sections.name: Artisan's Outfit

sections.body: These clothes are for performing priestly functions, not for adventuring. Cleric's vestments typically include a cassock, stole, and surplice.
sections.name: Cleric's Vestments

sections.body: This outfit includes a wool coat, linen shirt, wool cap, heavy cloak, thick pants or skirt, and boots. This outfit grants a +5 circumstance bonus on Fortitude saving throws against exposure to cold weather.
sections.name: Cold-Weather Outfit

sections.body: This outfit includes fancy, tailored clothes in whatever fashion happens to be the current style in the courts of the nobles. Anyone trying to influence nobles or courtiers while wearing street dress will have a hard time of it (–2 penalty on Charisma-based skill checks to influence such individuals). If you wear this outfit without jewelry (costing an additional 50 gp), you look like an out-of-place commoner.
sections.name: Courtier's Outfit

sections.body: This set of flashy—perhaps even gaudy—clothes is for entertaining. While the outfit looks whimsical, its practical design lets you tumble, dance, walk a tightrope, or just run (if the audience turns ugly).
sections.name: Entertainer's Outfit

sections.body: This set of clothes is for someone who never knows what to expect. It includes sturdy boots, leather breeches or a skirt, a belt, a shirt (perhaps with a vest or jacket), gloves, and a cloak. Rather than a leather skirt, a leather overtunic may be worn over a cloth skirt. The clothes have plenty of pockets (especially the cloak). The outfit also includes any extra accessories you might need, such as a scarf or a wide-brimmed hat.
sections.name: Explorer's Outfit

sections.body: This simple outfit includes sandals, loose breeches, and a loose shirt, and is bound together with sashes. The outfit is designed to give you maximum mobility, and it's made of high-quality fabric. You can conceal small weapons in pockets hidden in the folds, and the sashes are strong enough to serve as short ropes.
sections.name: Monk's Outfit

sections.body: These clothes are designed specifically to be expensive and gaudy. Precious metals and gems are worked into the clothing. A would-be noble also needs a signet ring and jewelry (worth at least 100 gp) to accessorize this outfit.
sections.name: Noble's Outfit

sections.body: This set of clothes consists of a loose shirt and baggy breeches, or a loose shirt and skirt or overdress. Cloth wrappings are used for shoes.
sections.name: Peasant's Outfit

sections.body: This is just the clothing, not the royal scepter, crown, ring, and other accoutrements. Royal clothes are ostentatious, with gems, gold, silk, and fur in abundance.
sections.name: Royal Outfit

sections.body: Perfect for a scholar, this outfit includes a robe, a belt, a cap, soft shoes, and possibly a cloak.
sections.name: Scholar's Outfit

sections.body: This set of clothes consists of boots, a wool skirt or breeches, a sturdy belt, a shirt (perhaps with a vest or jacket), and an ample cloak with a hood.
sections.name: Traveler's Outfit

sections.body: These prices are for meals and accommodations at establishments in an average city.
sections.name: Food, Drink, and Lodging

sections.body: Poor accommodations at an inn amount to a place on the floor near the hearth. Common accommodations consist of a place on a raised, heated floor and the use of a blanket and a pillow. Good accommodations consist of a small, private room with one bed, some amenities, and a covered chamber pot in the corner.
sections.name: Inn

sections.body: Poor meals might be composed of bread, baked turnips, onions, and water. Common meals might consist of bread, chicken stew, carrots, and watered-down ale or wine. Good meals might be composed of bread and pastries, beef, peas, and ale or wine.
sections.name: Meals

sections.body: These are the common mounts available in most cities. Some markets might have additional creatures available, such as camels or even griffons, depending on the terrain. Such additional choices are up to GM discretion.
sections.name: Mounts and Related Gear
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Mounts and Related Gear

sections.body:
Barding is a type of armor that covers the head, neck, chest, body, and possibly legs of a horse or other mount. Barding made of medium or heavy armor provides better protection than light barding, but at the expense of speed. Barding can be made of any of the armor types found on Table: Armor and Shields.

Armor for a horse (a Large nonhumanoid creature) costs four times as much as human armor (a Medium humanoid creature) and also weighs twice as much (see Table: Armor for Unusual Creatures). If the barding is for a pony or other Medium mount, the cost is only double, and the weight is the same as for Medium armor worn by a humanoid. Medium or heavy barding slows a mount that wears it, as shown on the table below.

Flying mounts can't fly in medium or heavy barding.

Removing and fitting barding takes five times as long as the figures given on Table: Donning Armor. A barded animal cannot be used to carry any load other than a rider and normal saddlebags.
sections.name: Barding, Medium Creature and Large Creature
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Mounts and Related Gear/Barding/Medium Creature and Large Creature

sections.body:
BardingModifier
(40 ft.)(50 ft.)(60 ft.)
Medium30 ft.35 ft.40 ft.
Heavy30 ft.*35 ft.*40 ft.*
* A mount wearing heavy armor moves at only triple its normal speed when running instead of quadruple.
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Mounts and Related Gear/Barding/Medium Creature and Large Creature/Barding
sections.name: Barding

sections.body: This is headgear used by a rider to control a mount. Bit and bridles for horses, ponies, and riding dogs can be readily purchased in most settlements and bits and bridles can be crafted for any creature that serves as a mount.
sections.name: Bit and Bridle
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Mounts and Related Gear/Bit and Bridle

sections.body: This Small, combat-trained dog is bred for battle; breeders favor strength, a thick body, and a low center of gravity. Guard dogs are sold in most large cities and some cultures use them for sport fighting or in some armies' special infantry.
sections.name: Dog, Guard
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Mounts and Related Gear/Dog/Guard

sections.body: This Medium dog is specially trained to carry a Small humanoid rider. It is brave in combat like a combat-trained horse. Due to its smaller stature, you take no damage when you fall from a riding dog.
sections.name: Dog, Riding
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Mounts and Related Gear/Dog/Riding

sections.body: Donkeys and mules are stolid in the face of danger, hardy, surefooted, and capable of carrying heavy loads over vast distances. Unlike a horse, a donkey or a mule is willing (though not eager) to enter dungeons and other strange or threatening places.
sections.name: Donkey or Mule
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Mounts and Related Gear/Donkey or Mule

sections.body: Horses, donkeys, mules, and ponies can graze to sustain themselves, but providing feed for them is better. If you have a riding dog, you have to feed it meat.
sections.name: Feed
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Mounts and Related Gear/Feed

sections.body:
A horse is suitable as a mount for a human, dwarf, elf, half-elf, or half-orc. A pony is smaller than a horse and is a suitable mount for a gnome or halfling.

A war-trained horse can be ridden into combat without danger. See the Handle Animal skill for a list of tricks known by horses and ponies with combat training.
sections.name: Horse
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Mounts and Related Gear/Horse

sections.body: These sturdy, weatherproof bags are draped over a saddle to add extra carrying capacity. Each side of a saddlebag can typically carry 20 pound of items that can fit in the bags. Saddlebags do not increase the amount of weight a mount can carry; they merely give riders a place to stow their equipment.
sections.name: Saddlebags
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Mounts and Related Gear/Saddlebags

sections.body: An exotic saddle is designed for an unusual mount. Exotic saddles come in military, pack, and riding styles.
sections.name: Saddle, Exotic
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Mounts and Related Gear/Saddle/Exotic

sections.body: This saddle braces the rider, providing a +2 circumstance bonus on Ride checks related to staying in the saddle. If you're knocked unconscious while in a military saddle, you have a 75% chance to stay in the saddle.
sections.name: Saddle, Military
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Mounts and Related Gear/Saddle/Military

sections.body: A pack saddle holds gear and supplies, but not a rider. It holds as much gear as the mount can carry.
sections.name: Saddle, Pack
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Mounts and Related Gear/Saddle/Pack

sections.body: If you are knocked unconscious while in a riding saddle, you have a 50% chance to stay in the saddle.
sections.name: Saddle, Riding
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Mounts and Related Gear/Saddle/Riding

sections.body: This is the amount it costs to stable a single creature that is Large or smaller for one day, at a typical stable or hostler. Particularly fancy stables may cost more, and larger or more exotic creatures cost double.
sections.name: Stabling
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Mounts and Related Gear/Stabling

sections.body: The prices listed are to purchase the vehicle. These prices generally exclude crew or animals.
sections.name: Transport

sections.body: This four-wheeled vehicle can transport as many as four people within an enclosed cab, plus two drivers. In general, two horses (or other beasts of burden) draw it. A carriage comes with the harness needed to pull it.
sections.name: Carriage

sections.body: This two-wheeled vehicle can be drawn by a single horse (or other beast of burden). It comes with a harness.
sections.name: Cart

sections.body: This three-masted ship has 70 oars on either side and requires a total crew of 200. A galley is 130 feet long and 20 feet wide, and can carry 150 tons of cargo or 250 soldiers. For 8,000 gp more, it can be fitted with a ram and castles with firing platforms fore, aft, and amidships. This ship cannot make sea voyages and sticks to the coast. It moves about 4 miles per hour when being rowed or under sail.
sections.name: Galley

sections.body: This 50- to 75-foot-long ship is 15 to 20 feet wide and has a few oars to supplement its single mast with a square sail. It has a crew of 8 to 15 and can carry 40 to 50 tons of cargo or 100 soldiers. It can make sea voyages, as well as sail down rivers (thanks to its flat bottom). It moves about 1 mile per hour.
sections.name: Keelboat

sections.body: This 75-foot-long ship with 40 oars requires a total crew of 50. It has a single mast and a square sail, and it can carry 50 tons of cargo or 120 soldiers. A longship can make sea voyages. It moves about 3 miles per hour when being rowed or under sail.
sections.name: Longship

sections.body: This 8- to 12-foot-long boat with two oars holds two or three Medium passengers. It moves about 1-1/2 miles per hour.
sections.name: Rowboat

sections.body: A standard wooden oar used to propel a boat.
sections.name: Oar

sections.body: This large, seaworthy ship is 75 to 90 feet long and 20 feet wide, and has a crew of 20. It can carry 150 tons of cargo. It has square sails on its two masts and can make sea voyages. It moves about 2 miles per hour.
sections.name: Sailing Ship

sections.body: This is a wagon on runners for snow and ice travel. In general, two horses (or other beasts of burden) draw it. A sled comes with the harness needed to pull it.
sections.name: Sled

sections.body: A four-wheeled, open vehicle for transporting heavy loads. Two horses (or other beasts of burden) must draw it. A wagon comes with the harness needed to pull it.
sections.name: Wagon

sections.body: This 100-foot-long ship has a single mast, although oars can also propel it. It has a crew of 60 to 80 rowers. This ship can carry 160 soldiers, but not for long distances, since there isn't room for supplies to support that many people. The warship cannot make sea voyages and sticks to the coast. It is not used for cargo. It moves about 2-1/2 miles per hour when being rowed or under sail.
sections.name: Warship

sections.body: Sometimes the best solution to a problem is to hire someone else to take care of it.
sections.name: Spellcasting and Services
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Spellcasting and Services

sections.body: The price given is for a ride in a coach that transports people (and light cargo) between towns. For a ride in a cab that transports passengers within a city, 1 copper piece usually takes you anywhere you need to go.
sections.name: Coach Cab
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Spellcasting and Services/Coach Cab

sections.body: The amount given is the typical daily wage for mercenary warriors, masons, craftsmen, cooks, scribes, teamsters, and other trained hirelings. This value represents a minimum wage; many such hirelings require significantly higher pay.
sections.name: Hireling, Trained
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Spellcasting and Services/Hireling/Trained

sections.body: The amount shown is the typical daily wage for laborers, maids, and other menial workers.
sections.name: Hireling, Untrained
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Spellcasting and Services/Hireling/Untrained

sections.body: This includes horse-riding messengers and runners. Those willing to carry a message to a place they were going anyway may ask for only half the indicated amount.
sections.name: Messenger
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Spellcasting and Services/Messenger

sections.body: A toll is sometimes charged to cross a well-kept and well-guarded road to pay for patrols on it and for its upkeep. Occasionally, a large, walled city charges a toll to enter or exit (or sometimes just to enter).
sections.name: Road or Gate Toll
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Spellcasting and Services/Road or Gate Toll

sections.body: Most ships do not specialize in passengers, but many have the capability to take a few along when transporting cargo. Double the given cost for creatures larger than Medium or creatures that are otherwise difficult to bring aboard a ship.
sections.name: Ship's Passage
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Spellcasting and Services/Ships Passage

sections.body:
The indicated amount is how much it costs to get a spellcaster to cast a spell for you. This cost assumes that you can go to the spellcaster and have the spell cast at his convenience (generally at least 24 hours later, so that the spellcaster has time to prepare the spell in question). If you want to bring the spellcaster somewhere to cast a spell you need to negotiate with him, and the default answer is no.

The cost given is for any spell that does not require a costly material component. If the spell includes a material component, add the cost of that component to the cost of the spell. If the spell has a focus component (other than a divine focus), add 1/10 the cost of that focus to the cost of the spell.

Furthermore, if a spell has dangerous consequences, the spellcaster will certainly require proof that you can and will pay for dealing with any such consequences (that is, assuming that the spellcaster even agrees to cast such a spell, which isn't certain). In the case of spells that transport the caster and characters over a distance, you will likely have to pay for two castings of the spell, even if you aren't returning with the caster.

In addition, not every town or village has a spellcaster of sufficient level to cast any spell. In general, you must travel to a small town (or larger settlement) to be reasonably assured of finding a spellcaster capable of casting 1st-level spells, a large town for 2nd-level spells, a small city for 3rd- or 4th-level spells, a large city for 5th- or 6th-level spells, and a metropolis for 7th- or 8th-level spells. Even a metropolis isn't guaranteed to have a local spellcaster able to cast 9th-level spells.
sections.name: Spellcasting
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Spellcasting and Services/Spellcasting
